fields.label_text:
Bowl
Made in Mexico about 1600-50
Red earthenware with painted decoration

314-1872

This piece was previously thought to have come from Talavera, Spain.

BOWL 1650-1750 Drinking vessels from the Mexican state of Jalisco were widely exported to Europe. They were particularly associated with chocolate drinking and continued to be made until the 19th century. The special earthenware, known as bùcaro, is scented and like chocolate itself was believed to have medicinal properties. Jalisco, Mexico Earthenware Museum no.314-1872 Exhibition: 'So Noble a Confection: Producing and Consuming Chocolate, 1600-1980' (19 October 2010 - 14 September 2011; Sackler Centre Entrance Lobby)

fields.descriptive_line: Bowl, made in Mexico, about 1650-1750, red earthenware with painted decoration

fields.name: So Noble a Confection: Producing and Consuming Chocolate
fields.venue: Victoria and Albert Museum, Sackler Centre

fields.physical_description: Red earthenware bowl coated with white slip and freehand painted deocration. Made in Mexico.
fields.label: Bowl Made in Mexico about 1600-50 Red earthenware with painted decoration 314-1872 This piece was previously thought to have come from Talavera, Spain. [16/07/2008] BOWL 1650-1750 Drinking vessels from the Mexican state of Jalisco were widely exported to Europe. They were particularly associated with chocolate drinking and continued to be made until the 19th century. The special earthenware, known as bùcaro, is scented and like chocolate itself was believed to have medicinal properties. Jalisco, Mexico Earthenware Museum no.314-1872 Exhibition: 'So Noble a Confection: Producing and Consuming Chocolate, 1600-1980' (19 October 2010 - 14 September 2011; Sackler Centre Entrance Lobby) [19/10/2010 - 14/09/2011]
fields.public_access_description:
Highly-polished earthenware vessels from Tonalá, in the Mexican state of Jalisco, were not only admired by the colonial settlers but exported to Europe in quantities from the early 17th century. The fashion for bùcaros de Indias (aromatic earthenware from Latin America) is well recorded in accounts and Spanish still-life paintings of the period. The vessels were celebrated for their fine and fragrant clay body, which infused a delicate flavour to the water contained within them. Fashionable Spanish ladies were known to eat small fragments of the bùcaros to benefit from certain gastronomic qualities. The aroma could be enhanced by storing the absorbent clay vessels in boxes scented with spices and oils.

Large, dimpled vessels were used to store water. The increased surface area aided evaporation through the thin walls of the unglazed clay. This served to humidify the hot and dry Spanish air. The process also cooled the remaining liquid and released the celebrated aroma of the clay.


Smaller beakers are often characterised by punched, stamped and incised decoration. These delicate vessels appear in many 17th century Spanish still-life paintings, demonstrating that bùcaros  were as prized as oriental porcelain or fine glass. Contemporary sources record their use in flavouring water at banquets. They were also thought to purify polluted water and even detect poisoned liquids.

By the end of the 17th century bùcaros were coated in a white slip as well as the usual red. They were decorated with freehand designs in red, orange, blue and black. The most common form of this type was a bowl with handles set at an angle to aid the user in drinking from it. These vessels were particularly associated with the practice of chocolate drinking and they continued to be made through the 19th century.
fields.exhibition_history: So Noble a Confection: Producing and Consuming Chocolate (Victoria and Albert Museum 01/10/2010-01/11/2011)
fields.bibliography:
Ray, Anthony. <u>Spanish Pottery 1248-1898</u>. London : V&A Publications, 2000.
Maxwell, Christopher. Let them eat clay: Mexican búcaros in the Victoria and Albert Museum, London. <u>Keramos</u>. 2010 (209), pp. 3-16.
See p. 14, plate 15, for a colour illustration of this piece.
fields.production_note: This piece was previously thought to have come from Talavera, Spain.

Highly-polished earthenware vessels from Tonalá, in the Mexican state of Jalisco, were not only admired by the colonial settlers but exported to Europe in quantities from the early 17th century. The fashion for bùcaros de Indias (aromatic earthenware from Latin America) is well recorded in accounts and Spanish still-life paintings of the period. The vessels were celebrated for their fine and fragrant clay body, which infused a delicate flavour to the water contained within them. Fashionable Spanish ladies were known to eat small fragments of the bùcaros to benefit from certain gastronomic qualities. The aroma could be enhanced by storing the absorbent clay vessels in boxes scented with spices and oils.

Large, dimpled vessels were used to store water. The increased surface area aided evaporation through the thin walls of the unglazed clay. This served to humidify the hot and dry Spanish air. The process also cooled the remaining liquid and released the celebrated aroma of the clay.


Smaller beakers are often characterised by punched, stamped and incised decoration. These delicate vessels appear in many 17th century Spanish still-life paintings, demonstrating that bùcaros  were as prized as oriental porcelain or fine glass. These vessels were particularly associated with the practice of chocolate drinking and they continued to be made through the 19th century.
